ratings.comment: Do all the homework as that is what a lot of your grade is based on. Even if it isn't done well, turning something in on time or late is better than nothing. Also, do the study guides provided because the test questions are very similar to them. Also, participate in class as much as possible or at least once or twice a class period.
Expect to have a lot on grammar in this course. He will start taking off more and more on hw throughout the course. The assignments are lengthy and busywork. Class time can go by very slow.

He looks for perfect grammar in a reading class. Your grade doesn't improve no matter how hard you work on the course materials, for he tests on grammar and wants you to do grammar synopsis for homework. Do not take him without superb grammar knowledge.

You really have to attend class. You can tell he's very passionate about the course, but even so the lectures are long and dry, but for me its difficult to listen to any history class and just be talked to for an hour and fifteen minutes. Also your whole grade is 3 quizzes and 2 bluebooks, with an extra credit paper option.

Marc was okay.  He had organized lectures but he's so boring.  He reads off of a piece of paper.  The content is super interesting but you may find yourself staring into space while he's talking.  Quizzes were too specific.  Midterm and final were predictable but graded inconsistently and completely not transparent with little feedback.
Marc is a good, organized lecturer who speaks clearly. The class was somewhat boring, but the material is pretty interesting. Would not recommend for non-history majors.

He's smart and interesting but totally condescending. The way he responds to you makes you never want to answer a question!! The movies were decent, but the class is really for Film people, I wouldn't suggest it for German majors. Bogus psychoanalysation of costumes, props, and facial expressions - not my thing. "crisis of masculinity" lol
Expect a quiz everyweek. The class periods are spent going over the assignment we recieved the lesson prior.

He likes to hear himself talk. His lectures weren't helful. Furthermore, he wasn't helful when approached after class. His responses were always "look it up in the text book." I highly discourage anyone from taking a course by him.

He's a decent teacher who knows what he's talking about.  He likes to call on people who don't know the answer, but what can you expect?  He's very helpful and totally doesn't put you down when you don't know a word.

Silberman is a German Film genius. He knows everything there is 2 know about it. He's helpful & interesting but tends 2 go on tangents & talk a lot -but for good reason; he knows his stuff. If u dont do readings you can make it easily but assignments & film screenings r essential. B sure 2 get on his good side -he picks favorites (but is fair)

Likes to hear himself talk... alot. His lectures are unnecessarily wordy and his discussion are basically him talking at you and not letting the students do any discussing. Tests are fairly easily with only one or two obsurce IDs per test but besides that tests are managable. Grading is alot like history courses- easy.

Prof Silberman is a good teacher, the readings are essentially optional as they don't really help you write the papers (which is almost your entire grade).  The papers aren't too difficult if you've taken Com Arts 350.  Overall I'd recommend the course and Silberman.

Silberman is a German Film genius!!! He really knows his stuff. He doesn't check readings, which gives you more flexibility of when you read them, but this class is somewhat writing intensive (end of year paper is 15 pages.) Don't expect all of the films to be entertaining, but all of them are pretty interesting. Ask lots of questions about papers.
